Something that acts as or causes Confidentiality Breach

column3: Something that acts as or causes Authorisation Failure
Something that acts as or causes Re-identification
column11: Use this concept for reidentification in an internal context. For reidentification performed by external entities see concept UnauthorisedReidentification

column3: Something that acts as or causes Equipment Failure
column11: Here equipment refers to physical equipment

column3: Something that acts as or causes Equipment Malfunction
column11: Here equipment refers to physical equipment

column3: Something that acts as or causes System Failure
column11: Here system refers to both hardware and software systems

column3: Something that acts as or causes System Malfunction
column11: Here system refers to both hardware and software systems

column3: Something that acts as or causes Component Failure
column11: Here component refers to both physical and virtual components. The failure of a component may or may not also cause a failure in other related components or the systems they are part of

column3: Something that acts as or causes Component Malfunction
column11: Here component refers to both physical and virtual components. The malfunction of a component may or may not also cause a malfunction in other related components or the systems they are part of

column3: Risks and issues that have their basis in legal requirements and enforcement

column11: This concept was called "IllegalProcessingData" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Public Order Breach
Something that acts as a or violates an obligation - e.g. in a law, code of conduct, policy, contract
Something that acts as or causes Violation of Contractual Obligations
column11: This concept was called "ViolationContractualObligations" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Violation of Legal Obligations
column11: This concept was called "ViolationRegulatoryObligations" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Violation of Statutory Obligations
column11: This concept was called "ViolationStatutoryObligations" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Copyright Violation
Something that acts as or causes Violation of Code of Conduct
column11: This concept was called "ViolationCodeConduct" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Violation of Ethics Code
column11: This concept was called "ViolationEthicalCode" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes violation of policy which can be either internal or external policy
Something that acts as or causes Detriment
column16: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Julian Flake, Georg P. Krog, Fajar Ekaputra, Beatriz Esteves

column3: Something that acts as or causes Damage
Something that acts as or causes Material Damage
column11: The criteria for what is considered material damage is based in jurisdictional laws and norms

column3: Something that acts as or causes Non-Material Damage
column11: The criteria for what is considered material damage is based in jurisdictional laws and norms

column3: Risks and issues that affect the reputation of the organisation
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Credibility
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Customer Confidence
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Goodwill
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Negotiating Capacity
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Opportunity
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Reputation
Something that acts as or causes Loss of Trust
Risks and issues that affect or have the potential to affect society at large or specific groups in society
Something that acts as or causes Discrimination
Something that acts as or causes Harmful Speech
column11: This concept was called "HarmfulSpeech" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Personal Safety Endangerment
Something that acts as or causes Social Disadvantage
Something that acts as or causes Terrorism
Something that acts as or causes Impact to Rights
column11: This concept was called "ImpactToRights" in DPV 2.0. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right

column3: The infringement or breach of rights in a manner that constitues a 'violation' of those rights
column11: This concept was called "ViolationOfRights" in DPV 2.0. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Actions or measures that prevent an individual or group from exercising their legal rights.
column11: This concept was called "PreventExercisingOfRights" in DPV 2.0. Violation of a right is a bar for actionable actions by an authority. Other impacts on right may be found to construe a violation of the right, but that is not necessarily always the case i.e. not all impacts are violations of a right. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: A limitation or restrictions on the scope or exercise of rights
column11: This concept was called "LimitationOfRights" in DPV 2.0. The    limitation refers to the applicability and scope of the right, and not in the ability to exercise that right. Limitation is therefore fulfilment of the right and its obligations - but for a scope other than what was intended or expected. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: The refusal or withholding or denial of the existence or applicability of rights
column11: The denial of the right refers to the argument that a right does not apply at all for a particular case. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right

column3: Failure to meet or complete the fulfilment of rights
column11: Here unfulfilment refers to non-completion of the right's obligations and processes. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right

column3: Interference with or blocking of the exercise of rights
column11: In obstruction, the right is not denied, limited, or unfulfilled - but the requirements to enable exercise of the rights are increased to the point of discouraging or obstructing the exercise of that right. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right

column3: The gradual weakening or reduction of the scope and protection of rights
column11: Erosion of rights typically only applies to passive rights which always apply, since for active rights the exercise of that    right is what enables it. An active right can be eroded over time it is limited consistently and increasingly such that the scope of the right is reduced over time. Though specified as a plural i.e. 'rights', this concept can be applied to a singular right

column3: Risks and issues that affect or have the potential to affect specific individuals
Something that acts as or causes Harm to humans
column11: This concept refers to the general abstract notion of harm

column3: Something that acts as or causes Injury
Something that acts as or causes Child Violence
column11: This concept was called "ChildViolence" in DPV 2.0

column3: Something that acts as or causes Physical Assault
Something that acts as or causes Psychological Harm
Something that acts as or causes Sexual Violence
Risks and issues that have their origin in environment or can affect the environment at large
Things that cause or have the potential to impact financial resources
Something that acts as or causes benefits
column16: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Julian Flake, Georg P. Krog, Fajar Ekaputra, Beatriz Esteves, Axel Polleres

column3: Something that acts as or provides compensation - which can be monetary and financial or in other forms
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Something that acts as or provides rewards i.e. a benefit given for some service or activity that is not a payment or fee
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Something that acts as or provides payment e.g. to access a service or purchase resources
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Something that acts as or provides fees e.g. for using a service
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Something that acts as or provides renumeration which is in monetary or financial form
column16: Georg P. Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Something that acts as or causes Financial Loss which may be actual loss of existing financial assets or hypothetical loss of financial opportunity
Something that involves or causes judicial penalties to be paid
Something that involves or causes judicial costs to be paid
Bias is defined as the systematic difference in treatment of certain objects, people, or groups in comparison to others
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when humans are processing and interpreting information
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when a human assumes that what is true for an individual or object is also true for everyone, or all objects, in that group
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when a human makes an association or assumption based on their mental models and memories
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when hypotheses, regardless of their veracity, are more likely to be confirmed by the intentional or unintentional interpretation of information
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when showing partiality to one's own group or own characteristics
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when seeing out-group members as more alike than in-group members when comparing attitudes, values, personality traits, and other characteristics
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when similiar cognitive bias (conscious or unconscious) is being held by many individuals in society
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs due to developer experience and expert advice having a significant influence on rule-based system design
column11: Rule based system design also potentially introduces various forms of human cognitive bias
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs in or during requirements creation
column11: Requirements bias also represents occasions for the human cognitive biases to manifest
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when data properties that if unaddressed lead to systems that perform better or worse for different groups
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs as the type of consistent numerical offset in an estimate relative to the true underlying value, inherent to most estimates
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when a dataset's samples are chosen in a way that is not reflective of their real-world distribution
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when data records are not collected randomly from the intended population
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when a population represented in a dataset does not match the actual or real population that are being used
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when people from certain groups opt-out of surveys at different rates than users from other groups. This is also called as Participation bias
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs as a confounding variable that influences both the dependent variable and independent variable causing a spurious association
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when the dataset is subject to a different (i.e. non-normal) distribution (e.g., Chi-Square, Beta, Lorentz, Cauchy, Weibull or Pareto) where the results can be biased and misleading
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs due to pre-processing (or post-processing) of data, even though the original data would not have led to any bias
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when a trend that is indicated in individual groups of data reverses when the groups of data are combined
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when aggregating data covering different groups of objects has different statistical distributions that introduce bias into the data
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Bias that occurs when the mapping between inputs present in the data and outputs are more difficult to identify for some group
column16: Daniel Doherty, Delaram Golpayegani, Harshvardhan J. Pandit

column3: Discrimination is the treatment of a person or particular group of people differently, in a way that is worse than the way people are usually treate
Occurs when a person is treated less favorably than another in a comparable situation based on a protected characteristic (e.g., race, sex, disability)
Occurs when an apparently neutral provision, criterion, or practice puts individuals of a certain group at a disadvantage compared to others, unless it can be objectively justified
Discrimination based on a person's age, often impacting older or younger individuals
Discrimination based on a person's caste, a form of social stratification found in some cultures
Discrimination against individuals based on physical or mental disabilities
Favoritism towards individuals deemed more competent or superior, often at the expense of others
Discrimination based on a person's language, often linked to national origin or ethnicity
Discrimination based on a person's nationality or citizenship
Prejudice or discrimination against people based on their race
Discrimination against individuals because of their racial background or skin color
Discrimination against individuals based on their ethnicity or cultural heritage
Discrimination based on a person's geographical origin or residence
Discrimination based on a person's religious beliefs or practices
Discrimination based on a person's sex or gender, typically involving unequal treatment or stereotyping
Discrimination based on a person's biological sex
Discrimination based on a person's gender identity or gender expression
Hostility or prejudice against individuals who are or are perceived to be homosexual
Dislike, contempt, or prejudice against women
Dislike, contempt, or prejudice against men
Hostility or prejudice against transgender people or those perceived as not conforming to traditional gender norms
Discrimination based on a person's sexual orientation, typically against those who are not heterosexual
Discrimination against members of a majority or historically dominant group, often in the context of efforts to promote equality
